We are just a few hours away from the Nintendo E3 Direct, which the company has said will only be focused on software. The fact that we’ve arrived at this point negates a theory that Nintendo was going to debut its upgraded Nintendo Switch Pro, said to have 4K docked capabilities and a new OLED 4K screen, before E3 so it and its partners should showcase games using the new tech.
But that hasn’t happened. And unless Nintendo is just plain lying about today’s Direct being software-only, we’re not about to get an announcement during the show today either.
My theory is that while the Switch Pro does exist, that perhaps Nintendo has decided to push its arrival until 2022 instead of this holiday, given that both A) the current Switch is selling incredibly well and B) a global component shortage makes the idea of launching a brand new console in the next few months seem like a not great idea.
But this idea runs contrary to a recent Bloomberg report that said that Nintendo is spooling up production and could debut the Switch Pro as soon as September. And when I asked Bloomberg’s Jason Schreier if he still thought that was happen, he said he stands by the reporting of his colleagues (he didn’t write the original piece).
One aspect of that piece has already not panned out, however, as the article said it seemed likely that Nintendo would announce the Switch Pro ahead of E3, where unless that happens in the next (checks watch) three and a half hours, that’s not going to be the case.
I also don’t really understand why if they were planning a Switch Pro release in September or October 2021 like the article says, why they wouldn’t be at least announcing the new model now, at the world’s largest video game show where they are presumably about to show off a bunch of games that should be running on this new hardware. We already saw a new Mario + Rabbits game from Ubisoft that looked suspiciously good, and I expect to see more of that kind of thing today.
I supposed it’s possible Nintendo was using subterfuge and plans to announce the Pro today, but if not then, perhaps in some other Direct in a month or so. Again, it doesn’t make a lot of sense why they wouldn’t use the platform of E3 to announce the Pro, if its release date really is so close, so who knows what’s going on behind the scenes. But I am also prone to trust Schreier and the reliable Bloomberg team’s reporting.
I don’t actually expect to have any answers by the end of the day here, as Nintendo will likely stick to what they said and only show games today. But after that, it’s anyone’s guess what happens next with the Switch Pro and its reveal.

Durante muchos meses, incluso más de un año, hemos escuchado sonar rumores acerca de una nueva versión de la consola de Nintendo, la llamada “Switch Pro”. Por fin, la compañía japonesa ha presentado una nueva Switch, pero no es la que algunos esperaban.
Su nombre es Nintendo Switch (modelo OLED), y como bien lo indica, su mayor cambio se encuentra en la pantalla. Se trata de un modelo que sirve como actualización de la Switch estándar, pero sin cambiar mucho. De hecho, su mayor es un incremento en el tamaño del panel, el cual ahora es de 7 pulgadas (el modelo original tenía 6,2") y un cambio en la tecnología de la pantalla, que ahora cuenta con un panel OLED, en lugar del panel LCD de los anteriores modelos de la Switch.
Esta pantalla OLED cuenta con una resolución máxima de 1920x1080 píxeles y 60fps cuando está conectada al dock para usarse con un televisor o pantalla externa, según la web oficial de Nintendo. En el caso del modo portátil, la resolución continúa siendo de 1280x720 píxeles, igual que en modelos anteriores. Los bordes alrededor de la pantalla son un poco más delgados en comparación a la anterior Switch.
Esto significa que la nueva Switch no es ese modelo 4K del que hablaban los rumores, los cuales eran justamente eso, rumores que la compañía en ningún momento confirmó. No obstante, el cambio por un panel OLED ofrece un mayor brillo en la pantalla que mejorará, en teoría, la experiencia de uso de la consola en modo portátil, algo que claramente le importa mucho a Nintendo y parece ser su enfoque principal con esta actualización.
La compañía confirmó a Verge que la nueva consola no cuenta con un nuevo procesador o mas memoria RAM, lo que significa que no tiene mejoras notables de rendimiento o gráficos. Los JoyCons tampoco han cambiado, según declaraciones de Nintendo a Polygon. De resto, la nueva Switch OLED incluye 64 GB de almacenamiento, un puerto para conexión a internet (Ethernet) en el dock y mejoras de audio en sus altavoces, según el anuncio. Su batería continuará teniendo la misma autonomía, de entre 4 y 9 horas, dependiendo del juego al que estés jugando.
La nueva Switch OLED saldrá a la venta el próximo 8 de octubre por un precio de 350 dólares, lo que supone un pequeño incremento de precio (50 dólares) en comparación a su modelo anterior.

The new handheld console includes a 7-inch OLED screen and a wide adjustable stand. It costs $350.
Nintendo on Tuesday revealed its Switch OLED model, the long-awaited upgrade to its hybrid console. It'll be available on Oct. 8 -- the day Metroid Dread comes out -- and will cost $350, or $50 more than the original. As of Wednesday morning, Best Buy and GameSpot had product pages for the new Switch, but you can't preorder just yet.
UK retailer Game has it up for preorder at £310, while Australia's EB Games has it for $539, but Nintendo hasn't announced official prices for those countries.
The 7-inch screen is slightly bigger than the regular Switch model's 6.2- and the Switch Lite's 5.5-inch LCD screens, but the new model's organic light-emitting diode display will offer more vivid colors and crisp contrast. It also features a wide adjustable stand (compared to the original model's flimsy kickstand), a new dock with a wired LAN port, 64 gigabytes of internal storage and "enhanced audio for handheld and tabletop play."
It offers the same 4.5- to 9-hour battery life as the regular Switch (the Lite lasts 3 to 7 hours), and uses the same Nvidia Custom Tegra processor. It weighs 0.93 pound (420 grams) with Joy-Cons attached, compared to the regular model's 0.88 pound and the Switch Lite's 0.61 pound.
It'll be available in two color variations -- one with white Joy-Cons and a matching dock, and the other  with neon red and blue Joy-Cons and a black dock. Your old Joy-Cons will also be compatible with the new model.
Nintendo's reveal mostly lines up with a Bloomberg report from earlier this year, but is missing one feature -- the ability to output at 4K to a compatible TV when docked.
UK and Australian prices weren't announced, but $350 converts to about £255 or AU$465.

Well, after all that talk about the Nintendo Switch getting new hardware, we have our answer. And it’s…somewhat confusing.
This morning, Nintendo has revealed the new OLED Switch, which confirms rumors that Nintendo was working on an upgraded version of the handheld screen with a better display and slightly bigger size.
But for all the talk about the “Switch Pro,” that OLED screen seems to be…more or less the most major upgrade for the new system, which is priced at $350 and will release on October 8.
The other additions the new hardware has besides the screen is improved sound from the handheld unit and a wired LAN port for the base. It also has an adjustable stand and 64 GB of internal storage. But for those who were hoping that this would be a power upgrade for the current Switch, which is now over four years old, that does not seem to be the case. There’s nothing at all listed about changes to the internal hardware of the Switch. The main draw is simply the screen, and unless Nintendo is hiding any performance upgrades, there…do not appear to be any.
The Nintendo Switch, of course, has not suffered from its lack of power compared to other consoles to date, so it may feel less pressure to upgrade itself in that way the way we see with other mid-gen hardware refreshes like the PS4 Pro and Xbox One X previously. But to have the main draw be a slightly better screen is a bit odd, and I’m not even sure if the actual resolution is improving past 720p. There’s nothing in any of the promotional materials about the screen’s resolution being enhanced, only that it’s now OLED tech. And rumors about the Switch “Pro” that it would have 4K capabilities when docked also do not appear to be true. Even the battery seems to be the same as the current model.
Even with somewhat minimal upgrades, even at a higher price, obviously the OLED Switch will sell out quickly when it arrives in October, as even the current base model is often hard to find. And many were wondering if Nintendo would actually debut new hardware at all this year in the midst of a global chip shortages affecting all manner of electronics across a broad range of industries, but here we are.
I find this kind of weird, to be honest, not what I was expecting from a “Pro,” but certainly nice quality of life features all the same. And it wouldn’t be Nintendo unless they were shrugging off expectations and doing their own thing in one way or another.

Les rumeurs et autres bruits de couloirs débouchent parfois sur des déceptions, et ç'a été le cas lors de l'annonce de la nouvelle Nintendo Switch (OLED) qui arrivera en fin d'année. Aussi, malgré une refonte de façade, la machine du constructeur japonais a-t-elle de réels avantages à faire valoir ?
C'est ce que nous allons tenter d'entrevoir dans cet article...
Aussi, Nintendo ne mise plus sur un rendu exceptionnel pour ses exclusivités depuis l'avènement de la Wii. Comme quoi, un hardware moins performant que la concurrence n'empêche pas le succès...
Telle que Nintendo la présente, la Switch OLED semble plutôt s'adresser aux habitués de la marque qui ont tendance à privilégier le jeu en mode nomade. Cet usage est d'ailleurs le cœur de cible de la firme nippone, comme le montre l'ajout d'un large support ajustable, permettant de poser la console un peu partout. Il faut dire que les optimisations de l'expérience sur téléviseur, via le nouveau dock, se résumeront à une connexion internet plus stable via le port Ethernet… Et notons au passage que la fameuse station sera aussi vendue séparément pour permettre aux propriétaires de la Switch actuelle de bénéficier de cet ajout. Inutile de racheter la console avec donc.
Les autres, et notamment les nouveaux-venus, risquent toutefois d'être dissuadés par le tarif élevé de la machine (environ 359 €) pour un « simple écran plus grand ». Finalement, Nintendo ne chercherait pas nécessairement à faire les yeux doux aux joueurs qui seraient restés à l'écart du phénomène Switch mais plutôt à consolider sa base de fidèles. C'est un fait, les fans sont parfois prêts à payer le prix fort pour obtenir la meilleure expérience possible sur leur console de prédilection.
Le point positif, c'est que nous pouvons aller jusqu'à espérer une baisse des prix sur la première Switch (et pourquoi pas sur la Lite) avec la venue de cette itération OLED… Presque tout le monde y trouverait alors son compte.
Au final, une hypothèse reste sur table... Et si la nouvelle Switch que nous venons de découvrir n'était qu'un modèle de transition avant une véritable version plus performante ? C'est une possibilité, car cette console s'appelle toujours Nintendo Switch et le terme « OLED » est notifié entre parenthèses. Nous sommes donc bien face à la Switch initiale, sensiblement revisitée.
Ainsi, rien n'indique qu'un modèle boosté (et 4K) n'est plus dans les tuyaux du constructeur à l'heure actuelle. Surtout que l'annonce de ce mardi sort un peu de nulle part, ne se greffant à aucun événement plus large, comme l'E3 par exemple.
Le contexte mondial particulier que nous traversons peut également expliquer, en partie, cette stratégie. De nombreux composants sont en effet touchés par des pénuries massives et Nintendo pourrait simplement ne pas être en mesure de lancer proprement sa machine cette année. Si bien qu'il ne serait pas étonnant de voir la Switch Pro être renommée « Nintendo Switch 2 », si sa sortie venait à être repoussée de quelques années encore (et à condition d'y inclure de vraies nouveautés marquantes cette fois).
Noël 96. Plein d’espoir, un pré-adolescent ouvre fébrilement le cadeau qu’il a repéré au pied du sapin. Le paquet est certes de taille modeste, mais il attire bien plus son attention que les gros parallélépipèdes bariolés qui trônent aux alentours, d’autant que son patronyme y apparaît clairement en lettres capitales…
Si Sony se défend de toute « course aux acquisitions », le rachat de Nixxes Software suit de très près celui d'Housemarque.
Xbox ne prévoit pas d'annonce de nouvelle console ou de mise à jour matérielle dans un futur proche, ni en 2021 ni en 2022.
Le TPS Scars Above, mélange de jeux de combats et d’énigmes, dévoile son univers de science-fiction et son gameplay à travers une vidéo d'une petite dizaine de minutes.

Everything you need to know about the Nintendo Switch OLED and why it's not the Nintendo Switch Pro ... [+] everyone was hoping for.
Nintendo announced the Nintendo Switch OLED model today, noting several times in the press release that the new screen will feature “vivid colors and crisp contrast.”
Here’s everything you need to know about the new hybrid Nintendo console.
First and foremost, this is not a Nintendo Switch Pro. It won’t play games with higher frame-rates or graphical fidelity. There is no 4K mode. All the stuff we were hoping to see in a Pro model? Sorry, none of that is happening beyond the nicer screen. That might be disappointing to some—I know I’m a bit disappointed—but the screen really does sound like a pretty major improvement.
Okay, tell me about the screen.
Sure. The new OLED screen is going to make games look better. For one thing, it’s 7 inches (instead of 6.2”) from corner-to-corner, adding valuable screen real estate in handheld mode. That’s where this slightly-larger Switch is really going to shine.
What makes OLED screens so great is the contrast. Every single pixel can turn off or on individually, which means blacks are much darker and images appear much more vivid as a result. I have an LG OLED TV and it’s gorgeous. Many people now have OLED screens on their mobile devices now as well. The OLED screen will bring the Nintendo Switch into the modern era...mostly. Just not if you want 4K or 60 frames-per-second.
These sound symbols prove that the OLED Switch has better speakers.
The Nintendo Switch OLED features improved audio in handheld mode, so your games won’t just look better they’ll sound better also. Never discount the importance of audio improvements to video games, though you’re still probably better off with a headset.
The Nintendo Switch OLED vastly improves the design of the tabletop-mode stand which was pretty flimsy in the original model. Here’s a pic:
That’s a major improvement and should make tabletop mode much more viable. Not sure how much people actually use that mode, but with a larger screen and a better stand it’s at least more viable.
Finally, for TV mode—with the Switch OLED docked and hooked up via HDMI to a TV—there’s now a LAN port so that you can hardwire your Switch to the internet instead of relying on WiFi only. That’s great for competitive online games and for anyone with shoddy WiFi.
As you can see, the screen is bigger and there’s a LAN input and it weights just a tiny bit more, but mostly it’s the same machine. Mostly.
If you can even find one of these at launch—and I wouldn’t get your hopes up—the MSRP is $349.99. Of course we live in a very silly timeline and scalpers have super-powered AI bots to do their bidding, so I’m sure we’ll see these sell for way more than MSRP. Don’t buy into that crap.
My recommendation? Hold out and wait for the price to return to normal.
No, of course not. A fool and his money are soon parted, as the saying goes, but if you want to drop $500 on one of these instead of waiting a few months go for it. I wouldn’t advise it but when have you ever listened to me in the first place?
Exactly.
I have another question.
Yeah okay, that’s what I’m here for. Ask away.
It’s kind of a big one.
Yep, go for it.
That’s a great question, you’re very smart to ask it.
Thank you.
And very attractive, I might add.
You’re too kind.
No seriously, it really is a very smart question. Unfortunately, I don’t have an answer for you. Joy-Con drift continues to plague Switch consoles everywhere and it’s super frustrating. Even the Nintendo Switch Lite, which doesn’t have detachable Joy-Con controllers, suffers from drift. My guess is that the OLED version doesn’t fix the problem, especially since it’s compatible with previous Joy-Cons. But I want to believe.
I also want to believe.
Well we can believe together and then later we can suffer together when our hopes are crushed and our dreams are dashed. Any other questions?
Yes! At launch, there will be a neon blue/red model and a black and white model. You can see that black and white model in action at the top of this post and it is—if I may be so bold—very sexy.
You may be so bold.
Thank you, that’s very kind of you.
I mean, I agree it’s very sexy. For a video game console.
I have another question.
Shoot.
Nintendo hasn’t announced one but it’s basically a no-brainer at this point so I would count on it—probably in 2022 or maybe even by the holiday season. I imagine it would feature a slightly bigger screen than the current model with “vivid colors and crisp contrast.”
That’s also pretty sexy. When you talk about vivid colors and crisp contrast, I mean.
Ha, thanks. Anything else?
That about does it. I guess I just need to know the release date.
Sure, no problem. The Nintendo Switch OLED Model with its vivid colors and crisp contrast will release on October 8th alongside Metroid Dread, the first 2D Metroid game in nearly 20 years.
Okay, stop it, that just makes me feel old.
You and me both, pal. You and me both.
Okay we’re getting way off topic here, but sure that was a great video game console. My very first game console actually. If that’s all the questions—
—okay, har har har. You got me.
